description: Bitcoin is the first cryptocurrency, created in 2009 by Satoshi Nakamoto. It’s a decentralized currency not controlled by any government.
Ethereum is a blockchain that supports smart contracts. It's the foundation for many DeFi apps and NFTs.
A wallet stores your crypto. Can be software (like MetaMask) or hardware (like Ledger). Never share your seed phrase!
Any cryptocurrency that isn't Bitcoin is an altcoin — includes ETH, SOL, ADA, etc.
A blockchain is a public, decentralized ledger that records transactions across many computers so that records can't be altered retroactively.
Self-executing code on a blockchain that automatically enforces agreements when conditions are met.
Non-Fungible Token — a unique digital asset that represents ownership of digital or physical items like art, music, or real estate.
Fees paid to miners or validators to process and confirm transactions on a blockchain like Ethereum.
Decentralized Finance — financial services like lending, borrowing, and trading built on blockchains without intermediaries.
A cryptocurrency pegged to a stable asset like USD (e.g., USDT, USDC) to reduce volatility.
The process of validating blockchain transactions and earning rewards, often using powerful computers.
Locking up crypto to support a network and earn rewards in a Proof of Stake blockchain.
A platform (like Binance or Coinbase) where users can buy, sell, or trade cryptocurrencies.
A digital asset built on an existing blockchain, like ERC-20 tokens on Ethereum.
A digital record of all blockchain transactions. Each participant has access to an identical copy.
Decentralized Autonomous Organization — an entity governed by smart contracts and community voting, without centralized leadership.
A secret code that proves ownership of your crypto. Never share it with anyone.
A cryptographic code used to receive cryptocurrency — like your crypto email address.
A list of 12–24 words used to recover your wallet. Anyone with it can access your funds.
How easily an asset can be bought or sold without affecting its price.
A way to earn rewards by lending or staking crypto assets in DeFi protocols.
Free distribution of tokens to promote a project or reward loyal users.
Traditional government-issued currency like USD, EUR, or NGN.
Originally a typo for 'hold', now slang for holding crypto long-term regardless of market swings.
A person or entity that holds a large amount of cryptocurrency and can influence the market.
A market condition where prices are rising or expected to rise.
A market condition where prices are falling or expected to fall.
Decentralized Application — software that runs on a blockchain instead of centralized servers.
Initial Coin Offering — a fundraising method where new tokens are sold to investors.
Exponential Moving Average (20) — a technical indicator that gives more weight to recent prices, showing the average price over the last 20 periods with an emphasis on recent data.
Relative Strength Index — a momentum indicator that measures the speed and change of price movements to identify overbought or oversold conditions.
Moving Average Convergence Divergence — a trend-following indicator showing the relationship between two moving averages of a coin’s price, often used to spot buy/sell momentum shifts.
Simple Moving Average — a basic moving average calculated by adding recent closing prices and dividing by the number of periods, giving equal weight to all data points.
